LOCATION: Regent Park
    
    SAFETY CONCERNS:
    - Assault: High, Auto Theft: Medium, Break and Enter: Low
    
    ADDITIONAL USER CONTEXT:
    Q: How long have you been living in this neighbourhood?",
A: I have been living here for about 10 years.",
Q: Have you personally experienced or witnessed any of these crimes?",
A: Yes, I have witnessed some cases of assault in the area.",
Q: Do you have any security measures in place at your home?",
A: Yes, I have a home security system and outdoor cameras.
ground_truth_context:
![City of Toronto](https://www.toronto.ca/wp-content/themes/cot/img/logo-print.svg)

# Child Safety

Parents and caregivers have an important role in reducing childhood injuries.

Injuries are the leading cause of death and one of the main causes of hospitalization for children zero to six years of age in Toronto and Ontario.

- Most injuries to young children occur in and around the home environment.
- Most injuries are preventable.

## [Child Injury Prevention](https://www.toronto.ca/community-people/public-safety-alerts/safety-tips-prevention/home-high-rise-school-workplace-safety/child-safety/child-injury-prevention/)

Information about how to prevent childhood injuries and create safer spaces for children.

## [Common Childhood Injuries](https://www.toronto.ca/community-people/public-safety-alerts/safety-tips-prevention/home-high-rise-school-workplace-safety/child-safety/common-childhood-injuries/)

Information for parents and caregivers on common childhood injuries.

![City of Toronto](https://www.toronto.ca/wp-content/themes/cot/img/logo-print.svg)

# Child Safety

Parents and caregivers have an important role in reducing childhood injuries.

Injuries are the leading cause of death and one of the main causes of hospitalization for children zero to six years of age in Toronto and Ontario.

- Most injuries to young children occur in and around the home environment.
- Most injuries are preventable.

## [Child Injury Prevention](https://www.toronto.ca/community-people/public-safety-alerts/safety-tips-prevention/home-high-rise-school-workplace-safety/child-safety/child-injury-prevention/)

Information about how to prevent childhood injuries and create safer spaces for children.

## [Common Childhood Injuries](https://www.toronto.ca/community-people/public-safety-alerts/safety-tips-prevention/home-high-rise-school-workplace-safety/child-safety/common-childhood-injuries/)

Information for parents and caregivers on common childhood injuries.

![City of Toronto](https://www.toronto.ca/wp-content/themes/cot/img/logo-print.svg)

# Your Personal Safety Checklist

Here are some questions to help you explore your personal safety. Just to make it easy, you should be answering yes to all of the following questions. If you answer no, have a closer look at the item to see if that is really how you wish to handle the situation.

At Home

![City of Toronto](https://www.toronto.ca/wp-content/themes/cot/img/logo-print.svg)

# Your Personal Safety Checklist

Here are some questions to help you explore your personal safety. Just to make it easy, you should be answering yes to all of the following questions. If you answer no, have a closer look at the item to see if that is really how you wish to handle the situation.

At Home

![City of Toronto](https://www.toronto.ca/wp-content/themes/cot/img/logo-print.svg)

# Home, School & Workplace Safety

## [Child Safety](https://www.toronto.ca/community-people/public-safety-alerts/safety-tips-prevention/home-high-rise-school-workplace-safety/child-safety/)

Learn how to keep children safe.

## [Smoking Safety](https://www.toronto.ca/community-people/public-safety-alerts/safety-tips-prevention/home-high-rise-school-workplace-safety/smoking-safety/)

Learn how to prevent balcony fires and more.

## [Home Fire Escape Planning](https://www.toronto.ca/community-people/public-safety-alerts/safety-tips-prevention/home-high-rise-school-workplace-safety/home-fire-escape-planning/)

Learn how to create your home fire escape plan.

## [Kitchen Safety](https://www.toronto.ca/community-people/public-safety-alerts/safety-tips-prevention/home-high-rise-school-workplace-safety/kitchen-and-cooking/)

Avoid danger in the kitchen by following these guidelines.
ground_truth:
1. NEIGHBOURHOOD-SPECIFIC ASSESSMENT:

Regent Park, a diverse and vibrant neighbourhood in Toronto, has seen a range of safety concerns over the years. Your specific concerns include assault (high), auto theft (medium), and break and enter (low).

- Assault: According to your account, you've witnessed incidents of assault in the area. Assaults can occur in a variety of settings and times, but they may be more common in areas with high foot traffic or during evening hours. 
- Auto Theft: Auto thefts are a medium-level concern. These are often opportunistic crimes, occurring when vehicles are left unattended or insecure. 
- Break and Enter: This is a lower-level concern in your area. However, residential break-ins can occur at any time, especially when homes appear unoccupied.

2. TARGETED SAFETY RECOMMENDATIONS:

- Assault: Consider enrolling in a self-defense course and always be aware of your surroundings. If you witness an assault, call 911 immediately. The Toronto Police Service also has victim services available for support. 
- Auto Theft: Ensure that your vehicle is always locked, even when parked at home, and avoid leaving valuables in the car. If your vehicle is stolen, report it to the police immediately. 
- Break and Enter: Continue using your home security system and outdoor cameras. Regularly check that they are functioning properly. Report any suspicious activity to the police.

3. PERSONAL SAFETY PROTOCOL:

Develop daily safety habits such as locking your doors and windows when you leave your home and when you return. Keep your mobile phone charged and close by.

Essential safety tools include your home security system and outdoor cameras. It may also be beneficial to carry a personal alarm.

Keep emergency numbers stored in your phone and posted in a central location at home. The non-emergency line for Toronto Police Service is 416-808-2222.

Community support services include the Regent Park Community Health Centre and the Toronto Police Service's Community Response Unit.

4. PREVENTIVE MEASURES:

For home/property security, continue using your security system and cameras, and consider additional measures like improved outdoor lighting or reinforced doors and windows.

Personal safety technology suggestions include mobile apps for emergency alerts and GPS location sharing with trusted contacts.

Engage with your local community through neighbourhood watch programs and community policing initiatives.

For reporting procedures, contact the Toronto Police Service directly for any incidents or concerns. In an emergency, dial 911. For non-emergencies, call 416-808-2222.

Please review the City of Toronto's resources on [Child Safety](https://www.toronto.ca/community-people/public-safety-alerts/safety-tips-prevention/home-high-rise-school-workplace-safety/child-safety/) and [Home, School & Workplace Safety](https://www.toronto.ca/community-people/public-safety-alerts/safety-tips-prevention/home-high-rise-school-workplace-safety/) for additional information.

## More Updates

[![](/media/filer_public_thumbnails/filer_public/71/6d/716dee26-1e4b-4084-ac13-6eb78983e6f8/46c8debb-f6f6-4a4a-a985-263bb29e0726.jpg__630x300_q85_crop_subsampling-2_upscale.jpg)](/crime-prevention/identity-theft-1/)

### [Identity Theft](/crime-prevention/identity-theft-1/)




Identity theft can happen to anyone. This rapidly growing crime affects more people every day in Toronto and around the world.

Yet, surprisingly most people think it will not

[![](/media/filer_public_thumbnails/filer_public/ce/6d/ce6dd200-694d-4040-a674-2f7a8ee49d83/449d58f4-4168-478a-a8ab-50e01f7a4e98.jpg__630x300_q85_crop_subsampling-2_upscale.jpg)](/crime-prevention/are-you-in-an-abusive-relationship/)

### [Are You in an Abusive Relationship?](/crime-prevention/are-you-in-an-abusive-relationship/)

- Create gathering areas at locations with natural surveillance and access control

- Re-designate the use of space to provide natural barriers to conflicting activities

- Improve scheduling of space to allow for effective use(parking for night shift workers closest to the building)

- Overcome distance and isolation through improved communications

- Place safe activities in vulnerable areas, e.g. community garden in vacant land

- Place vulnerable activities in a safe place, e.g. kindergarten play area in school courtyard

- Increase the perception of natural surveillance, especially around access control points


To report a crime anonymously, call Crime Stoppers at: 1-800-222-8477(TIPS) or online at: [www.222tips.com](http://222tips.com)

In An Emergency: Call 9-1-1.

To report a crime to the Toronto Police that is not an emergency call 416-808-2222.

ground_truth:
1. NEIGHBOURHOOD-SPECIFIC ASSESSMENT:

The Beaches neighbourhood exhibits varying safety concerns. The major concern is assault, followed by auto theft and break-ins. Though the area is generally safe, it's essential to be aware of these risks. 

Risk factors can be influenced by a variety of elements, including time of day, location, and personal behaviour. Nighttime hours might see a rise in assault-related incidents, particularly in less populated or poorly lit areas. Auto thefts can occur at any time but are more common in areas with less surveillance. 

2. TARGETED SAFETY RECOMMENDATIONS:

Assault:
- Prevention strategies involve being aware of your surroundings, avoiding poorly lit or deserted areas, and travelling in groups when possible.
- Warning signs can include suspicious individuals or behaviour. Trust your instincts and remove yourself from any situation that feels unsafe.
- If an assault occurs, call 911 immediately. Try to remember as many details as possible about the assailant to aid police.
- Toronto Police Service offers a variety of community resources, including self-defence classes and community watch programs.

Auto Theft:
- Prevention strategies include locking your vehicle at all times, parking in well-lit areas, and not leaving valuables visible.
- Warning signs can include suspicious individuals lurking near parked cars.
- If your car is stolen, call the non-emergency police line at 416-808-2222 to report the theft.
- The Toronto Police Service offers an Auto Theft Prevention Program, which can offer additional preventative measures.

Break and Enter:
- Prevention strategies include ensuring all windows and doors are locked, installing a home security system, and keeping the exterior of your property well-lit.
- Warning signs can include signs of forced entry, such as broken windows or damaged doors.
- If a break-in occurs, do not enter your home. Call the police at 416-808-2222 from a safe location.
- The Toronto Police Service offers a Home Security Audit Program, which can help identify potential vulnerabilities in your property's security.

3. PERSONAL SAFETY PROTOCOL:

- Develop habits such as checking in with someone if you'll be out late, locking your doors and windows when you leave home, and being aware of your surroundings.
- Essential safety tools can include a personal alarm, a well-charged mobile phone, and a list of emergency contacts.
- In an emergency, call 911. For non-emergencies, call the Toronto Police at 416-808-2222. 
- Community support services include neighbourhood watch programs, community policing initiatives, and local outreach programs.

4. PREVENTIVE MEASURES:

- Home security improvements might include additional lighting, security cameras, and reinforced doors and windows. 
- Personal safety technology might include apps like LifeLine Response, which can alert authorities if you're in danger.
- Engage with your community by attending neighbourhood watch meetings, local events, and safety workshops.
- Report any suspicious activity to the Toronto Police Service at 416-808-2222 or anonymously through Crime Stoppers at 1-800-222-8477.

Please note that these are general guidelines. For more specific advice, please contact the Toronto Police Service's non-emergency line.

Sources: 
- Toronto Police Service
- Crime Prevention Through Environmental Design - Toronto Police Service  
- Break & Enter Prevention - Toronto Police Service
- Transit Safety - Toronto Police Service
- Frauds Against Seniors - Toronto Police Service

    SAFETY CONCERNS:
    - Assault: High, Auto Theft: Medium, Break and Enter: Low

    Q: Do you have any security systems installed at your premises?",
A: Yes, we have CCTV cameras installed both inside and outside our building.",
Q: What is your main concern in terms of safety in your neighborhood?",

ground_truth_context:
Scams targeting older people are now called “the crime of the 21st century”, as they have become so widespread.

Seniors are actively pursued by fraudsters for many reasons, including

[![](/media/filer_public_thumbnails/filer_public/71/6d/716dee26-1e4b-4084-ac13-6eb78983e6f8/46c8debb-f6f6-4a4a-a985-263bb29e0726.jpg__630x300_q85_crop_subsampling-2_upscale.jpg)](/crime-prevention/identity-theft-1/)

### [Identity Theft](/crime-prevention/identity-theft-1/)




Identity theft can happen to anyone. This rapidly growing crime affects more people every day in Toronto and around the world.

Yet, surprisingly most people think it will not

[![](/media/filer_public_thumbnails/filer_public/78/b7/78b7153f-0bd7-4ec3-adb0-efa3ab5605f0/367f2f99-a9dd-489d-bc2e-be8116aefa36.jpeg__630x300_q85_crop_subsampling-2_upscale.jpg)](/crime-prevention/transit-safety/)

### [Transit Safety](/crime-prevention/transit-safety/)

**OTHER HELPFUL TRANSIT SAFETY TIPS**

* * *

- Never step in front of or out from behind a transit vehicle

- Do not walk across streetcar right-of-ways

- Never purchase transit tickets, tokens or passes from any place other than an authorized TTC agent - they may be counterfeit

- TRUST YOUR INSTINCTS - Trusting your own instincts that a situation seems “wrong” can be the best personal safety tool you have

- Pay attention to it and don’t be afraid to act on it. A moment of embarrassment, if you are incorrect, is far less important than your overall safety


For further information about public transit safety, check out the [TTC website](http://ttc.ca)

To report a crime anonymously, call Crime Stoppers at: 1-800-222-8477(TIPS) or online at: [www.222tips.com](http://222tips.com)

In An Emergency: Call 9-1-1.

To report a crime to the Toronto Police that is not an emergency call 416-808-2222.

## More Updates

* * *

- Do not allow yourself to be targeted, when waiting in a transit shelter. Exit the shelter if you feel threatened or uncomfortable

- Limit the use of electronic devices - this may target you


**Safety Tips When Using Public Transit**

* * *

- Sit near the bus or streetcar driver, use the lead car or sit in a Designated Waiting Area (DWA) while using the subway

- Be alert for people watching or following you

- If someone is bothering you, change seats or alert the bus driver

- Keep your personal belongings close to you (on your arm, between your feet, or on your lap). Avoid placing them under the seat where they can be easily stolen or forgotten

- Remain vigilant. Thieves will often use distraction or trick you to take out your device. (For example, asking you to give them directions or the time)

- Avoid using devices near the doors as it makes it easy for thieves to grab your property and run through the closing doors

</ul></description><pubDate>Thu, 08 Nov 2018 19:16:14 +0000</pubDate><guid>https://www.tps.ca/crime-prevention/transit-safety/</guid></item><item><title>Home Security</title><link>https://www.tps.ca/crime-prevention/home-security/</link><description><p>Home security can be as effective as you make it. Do not leave the responsibility for your safety and security to others. REDUCE YOUR RISK by practicing the crime prevention strategies outlined in this pamphlet. Together, you and your neighbours can work towards reducing crime in your area.</p></description><pubDate>Fri, 30 Nov 2018 01:06:02 +0000</pubDate><guid>https://www.tps.ca/crime-prevention/home-security/</guid></item><item><title>Auto Crimes</title><link>https://www.tps.ca/crime-prevention/auto-crimes-1/</link><description><p>By taking simple precautions, you can dramatically reduce the risk of vehicle theft or the loss of property from your vehicle.</p></description><pubDate>Thu, 08 Nov 2018

- Try to remember distinctive points of identification about the suspect and, if possible, write this down while it is still fresh in your memory

- If someone demands your property and displays (or implies) that they have a weapon, DON’T RESIST. You have a greater chance of getting hurt if you do

- If someone tries to assault you, ATTRACT ATTENTION. Activate the Emergency Alarm - Yellow Stripe Alarm, scream, run - do whatever you can to get away - ONLY YOU can decide how to respond to an attack


If you see trouble, ask yourself what are my options - can you cross the street or go into a nearby store? If you are heading to an unfamiliar area, did you get directions prior to departing or do you have the capability to look this up while enroute?

**OTHER HELPFUL TRANSIT SAFETY TIPS**

* * *

- Never step in front of or out from behind a transit vehicle

- Do not walk across streetcar right-of-ways
ground_truth:
1. NEIGHBOURHOOD-SPECIFIC ASSESSMENT:
Located in the heart of downtown Toronto, Kensington-Chinatown is a vibrant and bustling neighbourhood. However, like any urban area, it has its share of safety concerns. The most pressing concern in the area is assault, followed by auto theft, and then break and enters. Late nights and early mornings, especially in alleyways, are identified as particularly risky times. Having CCTV cameras could aid in deterring potential criminals and provide crucial evidence in case of an incident.

2. TARGETED SAFETY RECOMMENDATIONS:
    - Assault: The Toronto Police Service recommends trusting your instincts if a situation feels wrong. If you feel threatened, attract attention by screaming or activating an emergency alarm. Avoid walking in alleyways or isolated areas during late nights and early mornings. If you are attacked, remember distinctive points about the suspect for identification purposes (Source: Transit Safety - Toronto Police Service).
    - Auto Theft: Limit the use of electronic devices in the car as it might attract thieves. Park in well-lit and populated areas. Never leave your car running unattended. Always lock your doors, even when you're inside the car (Source: Auto Crimes - Toronto Police Service).
    - Break and Enter: Ensure all doors and windows are locked, even when you're home. Install a secondary lock or security bar on sliding doors and windows. Keep your property well-lit (Source: Home Security - Toronto Police Service).

3. PERSONAL SAFETY PROTOCOL:
Develop daily habits such as being aware of your surroundings, especially in risky areas or during late hours. Always have your phone fully charged and accessible. Save the emergency contact numbers of Toronto Police Service and local community support services. Utilise the CCTV cameras installed in your building effectively and ensure they’re always functional.

4. PREVENTIVE MEASURES:
    - Home/property security: Regularly check your CCTV cameras for functionality. Keep your home well-lit, especially entrances. Install a security system with an alarm (Source: Home Security - Toronto Police Service).
    - Personal safety technology: Consider carrying a personal safety alarm. Install local area safety apps on your phone for immediate alerts.
    - Community engagement: Participate in neighbourhood watch programs. Attend local community meetings to stay informed about safety concerns in your area.
    - Reporting procedures: To report a non-emergency crime, call Toronto Police at 416-808-2222. For emergencies, dial 9-1-1.

Remember, your safety is paramount. If you feel uncomfortable or threatened, don’t hesitate to contact the police or move to a safer location.

## Transit Safety

# Transit Safety

#### You Are in the Driver's Seat

PLAN AHEAD – use common sense and good judgment. Think about where you are going and plan your route before you leave. Consider:

• The time of day

• When the next bus/streetcar/train is scheduled, is the route delayed or out of service?

• How can you avoid walking through uninhabited or badly lit areas

#### **Crime Prevention on Public Transit**

**Safety Tips on the Street**

* * *

- Let others know where you’re going and when you’re expected to arrive/ return. Arrange to check in with them if possible

- Know where you are going and walk with confidence

- Avoid shortcuts (e.g. isolated areas/laneways/garages) and stick to well-lit/high-traffic areas to get to your destination.

As part of [City council’s mandate](https://secure.toronto.ca/council/agenda-item.do?item=2021.EX25.4) SCALE is a priority action in the SafeTO Community Safety and Well-Being Plan to develop a comprehensive strategy to share, integrate and analyze data across multiple institutions for the purpose of informing real-time policy development and service planning.

In 2023, SCALE launched the Community Safety and Wellbeing on Transit Dashboard [Community Safety & Wellbeing on Transit.](https://www.toronto.ca/city-government/data-research-maps/transit-community-safety-data/)

As part of [City council’s mandate](https://secure.toronto.ca/council/agenda-item.do?item=2021.EX25.4) SCALE is a priority action in the SafeTO Community Safety and Well-Being Plan to develop a comprehensive strategy to share, integrate and analyze data across multiple institutions for the purpose of informing real-time policy development and service planning.

In 2023, SCALE launched the Community Safety and Wellbeing on Transit Dashboard [Community Safety & Wellbeing on Transit.](https://www.toronto.ca/city-government/data-research-maps/transit-community-safety-data/)

ground_truth:
1. NEIGHBOURHOOD-SPECIFIC ASSESSMENT:

York University Heights is a vibrant neighbourhood with a diverse population. However, the area does have certain crime concerns. 

The primary concern is assault, particularly in the university campus area during late hours. Auto theft is of medium concern, while break and enter crimes are relatively low.

2. TARGETED SAFETY RECOMMENDATIONS:

Assault:
- Prevention strategies: Always be aware of your surroundings, especially during late hours. Try to avoid isolated areas and stick to well-lit, high-traffic areas whenever possible. 
- Warning signs: Suspicious individuals or groups, particularly those appearing agitated or under the influence. Trust your instincts.
- Immediate actions: If you feel threatened, make a loud noise to attract attention or run towards a crowded area. Dial 9-1-1 in case of an emergency.
- Community resources: York University Security Services provides a safe walk program for students, staff, and faculty.

Auto Theft:
- Prevention strategies: Never leave your car unlocked, even for a minute. Always park in well-lit areas.
- Warning signs: Suspicious individuals loitering around parked cars.
- Immediate actions: Report any suspicious activity to the Toronto Police Service non-emergency line at 416-808-2222.
- Community resources: The Toronto Police Service provides advice on auto theft prevention on their website.

Break and Enter:
- Prevention strategies: Install a good quality lock on your doors and windows. Keep your property well-lit.
- Warning signs: Broken windows or damaged doors. Unknown individuals loitering around your property.
- Immediate actions: If your property has been broken into, call the police immediately and do not touch anything until they arrive.
- Community resources: Toronto Police Service offers a Home Security Inspection Program where they provide personalized advice on securing your property.

3. PERSONAL SAFETY PROTOCOL:

- Daily safety habits: Stay alert and aware of your surroundings. Notify a trusted person about your whereabouts especially during late hours.
- Essential safety tools: Carry a personal alarm or whistle. Have emergency numbers saved in your phone.
- Emergency contact information: 9-1-1 for emergencies, Toronto Police Service non-emergency line at 416-808-2222.
- Community support services: York University Security Services, Toronto Police Service Community Programs.

4. PREVENTIVE MEASURES:

- Home/property security recommendations: Install good quality locks, motion sensor lights, and consider a security alarm system.
- Personal safety technology: Consider a personal safety app on your phone. 
- Community engagement opportunities: Participate in local community safety meetings or initiatives. 
- Reporting procedures and important contacts: Report any suspicious activity to the Toronto Police Service non-emergency line at 416-808-2222. In case of an emergency, call 9-1-1.

Remember, the Toronto Police Service offers several crime prevention programs and initiatives. More information can be found on their website (https://www.tps.ca/crime-prevention/transit-safety/). For anonymous reporting, contact Crime Stoppers at 1-800-222-8477(TIPS) or online at www.222tips.com.
